messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Akasaka Tsuba redux
messages.msgSnippet: G day Rich - My opinions are based largely on gut feeling when seeing the guard since, on photographs at least, these groups do resemble each other. Having
messages.messageBody:
G'day Rich -

My opinions are based largely on "gut feeling" when seeing the guard since, on photographs at least, these groups do resemble each other. Having the tsuba in-hand would of course make for a stronger argument for (or against) the groups mentioned, I would think.

Maybe I shouldn't had called the edge treatment "bones" but it would be the lines visiable from the three-fold construction of Akasaka. Last year I purchased a wonderful "willow tree" iron sukashi tsuba, mumei--one of my "dream" tsuba ever since Sasano illustrated this motif in his sukashi tsuba book. I felt it was Akasaka and it did have these linear lines (bones?) in its edge. Jim Gilbert and Henrik Eschbaum
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, May 13, 2004 7:53 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Akasaka Tsuba redux


Hey Ron, thanks for that, I can see the layers on the inside of the
nakago ana, but I am not seeing any bones in the mimi. I had not
considered either Higo or Nishigaki, why points yo uin that direction
?. My thoughts towards Tosa Myôchin are based on the the iron plate.
It is almost identical to this guard in the way the plate has been forged.

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/Tsuba/kuniyoshi-front.jpg

Thanks again for your help.

Rich




--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <swords@u...> wrote:
> Hi Rich -
>
> Yes, nice tsuba. It definitely is kiri, not wysteria motif. If
Akasaka I would expect to see some linear "bones" in the edge of the
tsuba from folding. I can see Akasaka or as you said, Tosa Myochi...or
dare I say Higo, Nishigaki work perhaps? Whatever, it is nice.
>
> Ron
> STL
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Tom Helm
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Wednesday, May 12, 2004 7:44 PM
> Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka Tsuba redux
>

> I would be more inclined to say Kiri (Paluwonia), rather
than Fuji
> (Wisteria), looking especially at the top. I think the crescents are
> just openings and not representative of any object...
> -t
>
> Nice piece, nice presentation too.
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka Tsuba redux
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich - Yes, nice tsuba. It definitely is kiri, not wysteria motif. If Akasaka I would expect to see some linear bones in the edge of the tsuba from
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich -

Yes, nice tsuba. It definitely is kiri, not wysteria motif. If Akasaka I would expect to see some linear "bones" in the edge of the tsuba from folding. I can see Akasaka or as you said, Tosa Myochi...or dare I say Higo, Nishigaki work perhaps? Whatever, it is nice.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Tom Helm
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, May 12, 2004 7:44 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka Tsuba redux


Rich-
I would be more inclined to say Kiri (Paluwonia), rather than Fuji
(Wisteria), looking especially at the top. I think the crescents are
just openings and not representative of any object...
-t

Nice piece, nice presentation too.

messages.subject: Akasaka Tsuba redux
messages.msgSnippet: Greetings all. I have new pics of this tsuba. I think it is Akasaka but could also be Tosa Myôchin. I am wondering about the theme here. Obviously a Wisteria
messages.messageBody:
Greetings all. I have new pics of this tsuba. I think it is Akasaka but
could also be Tosa Myôchin. I am wondering about the theme here.
Obviously a Wisteria branch and leaves but the two cresents ?, does
anyone have an idea of their meaning ?.

The images do not show the quality of the patina, it looks very well made.

Thanks for looking.

Rich Turner

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Akasaka-Wisteria-front.jpg

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Akasaka-Wisteria-back.jpg

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Akasaka-Wisteria-detail.jpg

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Akasaka-Wisteria-detail-2.jpg

Some variation on Ying-Yang?

Curran

that one I think :-) The square guard is great. Do you know what the 2
arcs or curved sections represent ?

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, I posted both the Akasaka tsuba I have in my folder. They are both papered (NBTHK & NTHK respectively) to Akasaka. Check there if this link does not
messages.messageBody:
Rich,

I posted both the Akasaka tsuba I have in my folder.
They are both papered (NBTHK & NTHK respectively) to
Akasaka.
Check there if this link does not work:

http://tinyurl.com/2mfvf

Compare it with yours. Similar central design element.
Along a timeline, I'd say yours definitely falls
chronologically between my 2 examples.

To be honest, I was a little surprised the Waterwheel
Tsuba papered to Akasaka. The photo's is odd/bad and
in hand the tsuba is more distinct, with nice iron
nodules. Iron is very refined, not needing to be so
heavily reworked as the 3rd gen? tsuba.

The 3rd gen? tsuba is very thick, and feels it was
hammered out from from a center mass. Heavy as a
brick.
From memory, dimensions are 68mm x 65mm x 6.25 mm.
Thins out about .75mm to 1mm to the mimi, with mimi
thickness greatest closer to design elements.

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, I would agree with you pretty much on every point. Has that Higo / Akasaka feel to it and iron looks cleaner, such that I would say mid to later Akasaka.
messages.messageBody:
Rich,

I would agree with you pretty much on every point.
Has that Higo / Akasaka feel to it and iron looks
cleaner, such that I would say mid to later Akasaka.

The central design is very similar to one of the 2
Akasaka tsuba I own (though shape and iron quality are
different). Basically a sense of 'swirling motion'
with paulownia flowers. It is one of my better tsubas
and I believe it to be probably 3rd generation or
around that time, though Jim G. has seen it and can
correct me.
Since the central design element is so close, I'll
try and photograph & post it for
comparison/discussion.

How thick is it at center? Does it thin out a mm or
2mm by the mimi?

Curran



--- Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...> wrote:
> All, a new purchase. An Akasaka ( mumei ) guard in
> Higo style. I was
> thinking probably mid/late Edo, and one of the
> Tadatoki school possibly
> ?. There is a guard that has similarities in Tosogu
> no Kansho that is by
> Tadashige ( Mid Edo ) P208.
>
> Any thoughts ?.
>
> Cheers
>
> Rich
>
>

messages.subject: Akasaka Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: All, a new purchase. An Akasaka ( mumei ) guard in Higo style. I was thinking probably mid/late Edo, and one of the Tadatoki school possibly ?. There is a
messages.messageBody:
All, a new purchase. An Akasaka ( mumei ) guard in Higo style. I was
thinking probably mid/late Edo, and one of the Tadatoki school possibly
?. There is a guard that has similarities in Tosogu no Kansho that is by
Tadashige ( Mid Edo ) P208.

Any thoughts ?.

Cheers

Rich

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/Akasaka_front.jpg

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/Akasaka_back.jpg

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/Akasaka_mimi.jpg

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] mei help please
messages.msgSnippet: I first thought mitsu also, but the loop in the first stroke doesn t make sense.  When writing in gyosho style the strokes flow together and there can be some
messages.messageBody:
I first thought mitsu also, but the loop in the first stroke doesn't make sense. When writing in gyosho style the strokes flow together and there can be some simplification, but you don't add in extra things. That loop stroke is usually used to combine a vertical and horizontal stroke.

The more "cursive" types of writing can look so stylized that it seems like anything goes, but they're still written based on the strokes and order of the basic "printing." Putting in an extra stroke changes the kanji.

Anyway,
Jim



Thanks Jim, always appreciated. A collector in Japan has suggested it is
MITSUTOSHI, KIKUOKA school. I was looking through the Mitsu's in
Murtha's book seeing if there was anything in there and I noticed
several Mitsu's written in a similar way, even though they are his
interpretation in writing, I though they were vaguely similar.

Cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] mei help please
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, It doesn t look like mitsu.  The bottom part of the first character is the same as in the bottom part of the gyosho style writing of sada (Self/Hirose
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
It doesn't look like mitsu. The bottom part of the first character is the same as in the bottom part of the gyosho style writing of sada (Self/Hirose 384) and kore (S/H 782), but the upper part of those kanji in gyosho or sosho style are different. I can't find any kanji that fit reasonably with a gyosho writing of the whole with that lower part.

Looking through the gyosho/sosho section at the end of the Daijiten I find a very similar rendering of AI / chika. The kaisho style writing of AI is much more complex, but here are two "script" versions of that character in the Daijiten:

http://tinyurl.com/37z8y

I don't find any makers listed with the name Airi or Chikatoshi, or under any variations I could come up with, including other possible but less likely kanji. The tsuba is interesting only because the workmanship is very similar to the many unsigned shiiremono variations taken from Kaneie and Nara styles. The taganemei also look like the ones on those shiiremono. Unfortunately there isn't a place or group name inscribed here. Given the workmanship I wouldn't be surprised if the maker has not been recorded, but I hope that someone can do better than me with the reading and research on this one. It'd be good to pin these things down.

Jim



Hi Gordon, Rich Stein has suggested, and cleverly so I think, that it
may be Mitsu (robinson 48) in a stylistic form.

Rich

messages.subject: Prayer Wheel tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Greetings, Would somebody please elaborate on the history, meaning and significance on the Prayer Wheel tsuba? Was it an armorers tsuba? What year was it
messages.messageBody:
Greetings,

Would somebody please elaborate on the history, meaning and
significance
on the Prayer Wheel tsuba? Was it an armorers tsuba? What year was it
created and used?

I thank you for your time and consideration!

J.V.
